author: Johan Steenkamp
title: Software Engineering
description: The purpose of this framework is to help you plan your career and to provide a clear structure of what is expected in different roles.

skills.title: Leadership
skills.details:
- Problem solving
- Leading by example
- Instigating change
- Growing teams
- Understanding what drives people
- Developing processes

skills.title: Mentorship
skills.details:
- Mentoring
- Coaching
- Identifying areas of improvement
and progression

skills.title: Technical Skills
skills.details:
- Breadth of experience (applications, services, domains, technologies, stacks)
- Knowledge of best practices
- Testing
- Refactoring and codebase improvements
- Tooling and awareness of progress in industry

skills.title: Communication
skills.details:
- Written and oral communication
- Explaining work to peers and non-technical stakeholders
- Proactive communication
- Developing and improving communication channels

skills.title: Emotional Intelligence
skills.details:
- Empathy
- Avoiding blame
- Awareness of team morale
- Taking active steps to improve morale

skills.title: Delivery
skills.details:
- Showing initiative
- Estimating effectively
- Ability to delegate
- Size and scope of the deliverables
- Understanding when to get support
- Impact on software team productivity

skills.title: Business Knowledge
skills.details:
Understanding of:
- Key industry verticals
- Company structure and strategy
- Product/vertical teams setup
- The goals of the product/vertical teams
- How value is delivered

roles.title: Software Developer (1)
roles.description: A Software Developer (1) has a solid technical foundation, and a strong focus on growing their development skills. Developers at this level are able to deliver small to medium-sized well-defined tasks, working individually or collaborating with others. They have a small amount of experience in a well-defined area.

skills.title: Leadership
skills.details:
Exhibits Syft's core values, focuses on understanding and living these values.

Able to identify and communicate problems with the product team and process.

**Example behaviours:**

- Raised a concern about inefficient workflow

skills.title: Mentorship
skills.details:
Collaborates effectively with other developers in the team.

**Example behaviours:**

- Work collaboratively with a developer on a feature
- Developing knowledge of a single component of our architecture

skills.title: Technical Skills
skills.details:
Broad knowledge of core CS concepts.

Focus on growing as an engineer, learning existing tools, resources and processes.

Small amount of experience in one area (application, service, domain, technology, stack, etc).

Able to identify and communicate problems with technology.

Able to suggest improvements to existing technology and tools.

**Example behaviours:**

- Added a component to software platform
- Shipped a small feature in the web app
- Increased test coverage
- Found and filed a bug

skills.title: Communication
skills.details:
Communicates with peers effectively and in a timely manner.

Accepts feedback graciously and learns from everything they do.

**Example behaviours:**

- Consistently writes good commit messages and release log emails
- Asked for help

skills.title: Emotional Intelligence
skills.details:
Displays empathy towards colleagues.

**Example behaviours:**

- Gave unprompted positive feedback to a colleague
- Checked in with a colleague who is struggling

skills.title: Delivery
skills.details:
Develops their productivity skills by learning source control, editors, the build system, and other tools as well as testing best practices.

Able to deliver small/medium tasks, working individually or collaboratively.

**Example behaviours:**

- Shipped a small feature on time without any support
- Added a new UI component

skills.title: Business Knowledge
skills.details:
Understands product/sales team's goals, and how they impact the company.

Understand impact of work on product/sales team and goals.

**Example behaviours:**

- Suggested features during a team meeting
- Explained product team's goals to a new starter

roles.title: Software Developer (2)
roles.description: A Software Developer (2) has a large amount of experience in a well-defined area, and works to support other developers in the team and leads by example. Developers at this level are able to deliver medium to large tasks to production, working independently if required. They use best practices to ship high-quality code, and continue to push their knowledge.

skills.title: Leadership
skills.details:
Able to identify problems with the team and process, and investigate potential causes.

Occasionally takes a lead in team processes.

**Example behaviours:**
- Facilitated a team retrospective
- Led a feature kick-off

skills.title: Mentorship
skills.details:
Supports new hires, mentors peers in an ad-hoc way.

Able to mentor new hires.

**Example behaviours:**
- Acted as a mentor buddy for a new hire
- Helped a developer understand how front-end works

skills.title: Technical Skills
skills.details:
Writes correct and clean code with guidance and consistently follows stated best practices.

Participates in technical design of features with guidance.

Rarely makes the same mistake twice, begins to focus on attaining expertise in one or more areas.

Learns quickly and makes steady progress without the need for constant significant feedback from more senior engineers.

Able to identify and communicate problems with technology, and investigate potential causes.

**Example behaviours:**
- Investigated flakey tests on Jenkins, and shared investigation results
- Extracted shared functionality into its own component
- Increased test coverage

skills.title: Communication
skills.details:
Communicates effectively with non-technical peers, able to present their work to the wider company.

**Example behaviours:**
- Delivered a Show and Tell presentation
- Acted as communicator during a support issue and updated appropriate stakeholders in a timely manner

skills.title: Emotional Intelligence
skills.details:
Displays empathy towards the users of our products.

**Example behaviours:**
- Voiced a concern about an existing bug that affects a large number of users
- Able to not panic during a user-facing support issue and identify the failing part of the stack, working with others to fix it

skills.title: Delivery
skills.details:
Able to own small-to-medium features from technical design through completion.

Capable of prioritizing tasks. Avoids getting caught up in unimportant details and endless "bikeshedding".

Capable of providing on-call support for their area including systems that they are not familiar with.

**Example behaviours:**
- Shipped a medium platform feature without any support
- Correctly estimated the amount of time a new GraphQL resolver would take to implement

skills.title: Business Knowledge
skills.details:
Able to ask questions/seek clarity on what the product/sales team is doing and why.

**Example behaviours:**
- Raised a concern about the team's goals
- Asked the team PM for clarification on why a particular piece of work had been prioritised

roles.title: Senior Software Developer (1)
roles.description: A Senior Software Developer (1) has a large amount of experience across multiple systems, and is able to estimate and reliably deliver complex tasks impacting multiple systems. They support and lead the technical direction in their team, and can communicate future plans and direction to technical and non-technical people.

skills.title: Leadership
skills.details:
Able to identify problems with the product team and process, investigate potential causes, and propose solutions/next steps.

Able to identify team and process areas that require ownership/improvement.

**Example behaviours:**
- Suggested a new way for team to collaborate
- Started and ran UI design meetup

skills.title: Mentorship
skills.details:
Able to deliver constructive, actionable feedback in an empathetic way.

**Example behaviours:**
- Suggested improvements empathetically during a code review
- Shared a blog post with a colleague to help them with a problem
- Identified when it would be more valuable for someone else to pick up a task (e.g. for educational purposes) instead of doing it themselves

skills.title: Technical Skills
skills.details:
Large amount of experience in multiple areas.

Able to identify and communicate problems with technology, investigate potential causes, and propose solutions/next steps.

Able to suggest improvements to technology and tools, investigate implementations and propose next steps.

Able to identify tech areas that require ownership/improvement.

Leaves things better than they found them.

**Example behaviours:**
- Investigated adding Jest to front-end, and shared results with the team
- Refactored a module in a service before adding functionality to it to make it more testable
- Took ownership of the support process

skills.title: Communication
skills.details:
Able to explain their work to the wider company, including to a nontechnical audience.

Practises active listening.

**Example behaviours:**
- Wrote a change note explaining the impact of a technical change
- Wrote a detailed and concise platform update email
- Listened to all points of view during a discussion without interrupting anyone

skills.title: Emotional Intelligence
skills.details:
Nurtures empathy and no-blame culture in their  team.

**Example behaviours:**
- Suggested how we can improve a process in the aftermath of a issue instead of identifying whose fault it was
- Understood the context for a certain piece of technical debt instead of apportioning blame

skills.title: Delivery
skills.details:
Able to deliver medium/large tasks that span multiple systems with support from peers.

Able to estimate delivery of work, and proactively inform the team when work is likely to be delayed.

Able to question and push back on work that is not valuable for the software team.

Able to effectively prioritise own workload and focus across many streams of work.

**Example behaviours:**
- Shipped a new microservice with support from colleagues
- Broke a large piece of work into smaller individual units that could be parallelised

skills.title: Business Knowledge
skills.details:
Able to understand company goals, ask questions, challenge company goals.

Seek clarity on what the company is doing and why.

**Example behaviours:**
- Asked a question about next quarter's goals at a company meeting
- Understand company's goals in a 1:1 with manager
- Able to clearly explain company goals to others in the team

roles.title: Senior Software Developer (2)
roles.description: A Senior Software Developer (2) has a large amount of experience across multiple systems, and is able to estimate and reliably deliver complex tasks impacting multiple systems. They actively coach and mentor developers in their team, and are able to identify and resolve issues with technology and product processes.

skills.title: Leadership
skills.details:
Able to identify problems with the product team and process, investigate potential causes, implement solutions/next steps, and proactively inform the right people of the change.

**Example behaviours:**
- Implemented a new bug-tracking process

skills.title: Mentorship
skills.details:
Actively coach/mentor junior members of the team.

Actively works to share information with the team, e.g. best practices, technical approaches (avoiding silos).

**Example behaviours:**
- Prepared and delivered a presentation on Git best practices
- Introduced a short presentation on JavaScript best practices as part of onboarding

skills.title: Technical Skills
skills.details:
Keeps up with industry best practices.

Enables other developers to work more effectively.

Able to identify and communicate problems with technology,investigate potential causes, propose solutions/next steps, and proactively inform the team of changes.

Able to investigate improvements to technology and tools and plan implementations.

**Example behaviours:**
- Made a plan to add Jest to stack, shared with the Architects for feedback, worked with the team to roll-out
- Shared results migrating to Webpack
- Wrote and published the account GraphQL components

skills.title: Communication
skills.details:
Can explain the impact of their team's work to non-technical stakeholders.

**Example behaviours:**
- Delivered a presentation about a technical migration at a company meeting
- Wrote a wiki post on the software group wiki

skills.title: Emotional Intelligence
skills.details:
Identifies morale issues in team, and works with team members to address or seeks support in doing so.

**Example behaviours:**
- Diffused tension between two participants in a retrospective

skills.title: Delivery
skills.details:
Able to deliver large tasks that touch multiple systems, working individually when required.

Able to estimate delivery of work, proactively inform the team when work is likely to be delayed, and suggest sensible workarounds/next steps to mitigate impact of delayed work.

**Example behaviours:**
- Reduced the scope of a feature in order to cut down development time
- Planned and executed a database migration that required downtime, informed the right people about it and sought the right support

skills.title: Business Knowledge
skills.details:
Able to communicate/explain and advocate team's goals to developers in the team.

**Example behaviours:**
- Clarified to a developer on the team why a particular piece of work was valuable
- Encouraged developers on the team to think about their work in terms of impact on the teams goals

roles.title: Technical Lead
roles.description: A Technical Lead represents the technology aspect of a product team, leading the technical direction, guiding developers, and communicating team progress alongside the Product Manager. Technical Leads have a large amount of technical experience working across multiple systems as well as great communication skills. They help keep the team focused and delivering value.

skills.title: Leadership
skills.details:
Able to identify problems with the product team and process, and encourage developers to own investigations and proposals for fixes.

Able to support and lead technical direction in a team.

**Example behaviours:**
- Ran a project kick-off meeting

skills.title: Mentorship
skills.details:
Actively mentors developers, identifying areas for focus and improvement.

Coaches developers to answers for their questions/problems.

**Example behaviours:**
- Did a workshop on how web application service works
- Worked with a developer to organise a programming session to remove an information silo

skills.title: Technical Skills
skills.details:
Keeps up with industry best practices.

Understands the impact of technology choices on the team.

Able to identify problems with and improvements to technology and tools.

Encourages developers to own investigations and proposals for fixes and improvements.

**Example behaviours:**
- Researched and chose a technology for the new product feature

skills.title: Communication
skills.details:
Can explain the impact of their product team's work to non-technical stakeholders.

Can explain the team's goals to their team in an engaging way.

**Example behaviours:**
- Delivered a presentation about a technical migration at a company meeting

skills.title: Emotional Intelligence
skills.details:
Able to read the morale of their product team and respond to their needs.

Works to actively improve morale in the product teams.

**Example behaviours:**
- Diffused tension between two participants in a retrospective
- Got the team excited about a potentially boring piece of work

skills.title: Delivery
skills.details:
Able to estimate delivery of work across the product team, proactively informing the stakeholders on progress.

Effectively manages deliverables for the team, ensuring the prioritised work is planned and valuable/aligned with our goals.

Actively works to remove distractions and low impact work from the software team.

**Example behaviours:**
- Delegated a task in order to focus on unblocking the developers

skills.title: Business Knowledge
skills.details:
Understand and communicate the goals across product teams, and how they contribute to the company's success.

Works to make sure developers understand the team and company's goals.

Help shape product team goals to ensure they're delivering value for the business.

**Example behaviours:**
- Worked with PM to pick a feasible metric for the quarter
- Had a 1:1 with a developer and gave them the context behind the quarterly goal

roles.title: Architect
roles.description: An Architect is an expert in a particular domain, such as a product or technology. Their role is to support and lead the technical direction across teams, share learnings, and effectively communicate future plans to product teams and the wider company. Architects proactively work with the team to identify areas for technical improvements and action them.

skills.title: Leadership
skills.details: Able to identify problems with the product team and process, investigate potential causes, work with the team to propose solutions/next steps, and make sure the fixes are prioritised and completed.

skills.title: Mentorship
skills.details:
Mentors groups of peers.

Coaches senior technologists in the team (e.g. Technical Leads).

skills.title: Technical Skills
skills.details:
Expert in a domain and understands the impact of technology choices on the company.

Solid understanding of entire technology ecosystem, and domain experts for different areas.

Able to identify problems with technology, investigate potential causes, work with the team to propose solutions/next steps, and make sure the fixes are prioritised and completed.

**Example behaviours:**
- Planned and executed timestamp encoding and database migration

skills.title: Communication
skills.details:
Proactively communicate future plans and direction to technical and nontechnical people across teams.

Work with product teams to help them understand how our software architecture supports the team's business goals.

**Example behaviours:**
- Created a detailed document outlining a change that we needed to make to our architecture, and delivered presentations to the software team and wider team to explain the business need

skills.title: Emotional Intelligence
skills.details: Detects and responds to the needs of teams and reports.

skills.title: Delivery
skills.details:
Identifies areas where major work needs to be done in order to support teams current or future goals.

Able to estimate, plan and deliver large projects using a small team.

**Example behaviours:**
- Researched and made a plan to move to a new data warehousing platform
- Identified the weaknesses of the existing monitoring system, researched a better one, and worked with the teams to move to it

skills.title: Business Knowledge
skills.details:
Understands the goals across product teams, and how they contribute to the company's success.

Help shape product team goals to ensure they're delivering value for the business, considering our technical strategy.

roles.title: Senior Architect
roles.description: A Senior Architect is responsible for leading the Architects group. They ensure the Architects are working effectively, by providing coaching, mentoring, and guidance where required. They organise the group in order to deliver value for the software teams and business.

skills.title: Leadership
skills.details: Able to identify problems with the product team and process, and encourage the Architects to own investigations and proposals for fixes.

skills.title: Mentorship
skills.details: Coaches Architects.

skills.title: Technical Skills
skills.details:
Expert across multiple domains.

Able to identify problems with technology, and encourage the Architects to own investigations and proposals for fixes.

**Example behaviours:**
- Moved company tech stack to new infrastructure
- Planned and executed moving to distributed architecture

skills.title: Communication
skills.details: Represent and communicate the role of the Architects, goals and priorities, deliverables, to the business.

skills.title: Emotional Intelligence
skills.details: Detects and responds to the needs of product teams, reports, and Architects group.

skills.title: Delivery
skills.details: Able to estimate, plan and deliver large projects using multiple teams.

skills.title: Business Knowledge
skills.details: Work with the Architects to ensure a technical strategy exists, and has been considered as part of the planning process.

roles.title: Engineering Manager
roles.description: An Engineering Manager works with a number of teams, supporting their developers and processes. They are responsible for managing developers across the technology team, guiding and supporting their growth. They ensure we have the right technical skills in the team to tackle the challenges the business is solving.

skills.title: Leadership
skills.details:
Support processes across several product teams.

Manage and grow the technology team.

**Example behaviours:**
- Identified an information silo and worked with the teams to mitigate it
- Found an internal talent development programme to help direct report grow

skills.title: Mentorship
skills.details:
Develops new coaches and mentors in the team.

Coaches direct reports, identifies areas for their progression.

Guide developers across teams, supporting development of their technical and product skills.

Help grow reports and highlight areas for progression.

**Example behaviours:**
- Identified an opportunity for a team member to be mentored by another team member and worked with them to make it happen
- Coached a developer to prepare and deliver a dev talk

skills.title: Technical Skills
skills.details:
Aware of the impact tools and technology have on development team productivity and happiness.

Management skills (mentoring, coaching,development, admin, planning, etc). Understand the technical challenges of the product teams.

**Example behaviours:**
- Has weekly 1:1s with reports

skills.title: Communication
skills.details:
Develops and improves communication channels between product teams.

Acts as a conduit between technology and other areas of the business, shielding and fielding questions where necessary.

**Example behaviours:**
- Organised and ran a weekly Technology Leadership meeting

skills.title: Emotional Intelligence
skills.details:
Detects and responds to the needs of teams and reports.

Ensures the team has a good work-life balance, and is taking enough vacation.

**Example behaviours:**
- Turned a problematic situation into an opportunity to learn and improve
- Identified tension between two team members and took proactive steps to remove it

skills.title: Delivery
skills.details:
Creates progression plans to develop careers of the technology team.

Ensure the technology team has the right expertise, working with the ED/CTO to inform the hiring plan.

Responsible for the technical hiring process.

Evangelises the work of the technology team, internally to other areas, and externally.

**Example behaviours:**
- Advertise open tech roles, review CVs, interview candidates, and run debrief sessions
- Ensure the team publishes a update about our latest software team initiative/achievement

skills.title: Business Knowledge
skills.details:
Able to question and contribute to company goals.

Understand and help to drive how product teams and reports deliver business value.

roles.title: Engineering Director
roles.description: An Engineering Director works across the technology team, managing managers and developing future leaders in the team. The Engineering Director identifies areas of focus for the technology team and their processes. They represent the software team to the rest of the organisation, and help shape the team's strategy.

skills.title: Leadership
skills.details:
Ability to identify and work with the team to fix problems with software team processes.

Support processes across several product teams.

Manage, grow, and help lead the technology team.

**Example behaviours:**
- Develop a quarterly peer review process

skills.title: Mentorship
skills.details:
Creates ways for people to mentor each other.

Guide developers across the technology team to solutions, supporting development of their technical and product skills.

Help grow reports and highlight areas for progression.

**Example behaviours:**
- Delivered a coaching workshop
- Introduced brownbag talks and lined up speakers

skills.title: Technical Skills
skills.details: Management skills (mentoring, coaching, development, admin, planning, etc). Understand the technical challenges of the technology team.

skills.title: Communication
skills.details:
Develops and improves communication channels for the whole software team.

Promotes Syft externally.

**Example behaviours:**
- Introduced the change note email and explained to the team why it's valuable
- Gave a presentation about Syft at jobs fair

skills.title: Emotional Intelligence
skills.details:
Proactively improves the morale of the engineering team.

**Example behaviours:**
- Organised a celebration of completion of a large piece of work

skills.title: Delivery
skills.details:
Identifies and develops future managers/leaders in the team.

Organises the Engineering Management group, providing coaching, support, and guidance.

Works with the CTO to determine the technical strategy, considering business focus, hiring, budgets, and the current team.

**Example behaviours:**
- Identified a future engineering manager in the team and gave them the right support to become one

skills.title: Business Knowledge
skills.details:
Understands and affects the role of the software team within Syft.

Understand how the technology team and other functional teams deliver business value, and use knowledge to help shape strategy of technology team.

**Example behaviours:**
- Influenced the company strategy by voicing the needs of the engineering team during planning
- Built a productive relationship between the technology team and the international teams
